text: So it is not the case that mammals are somehow unable to regenerate. But our capacities at present, and I do think this is changeable, are not as good as those of certain other organisms. Now, we've been studying for some years how it is that this happens. How does a collection of cells know what to build and when to stop? And we took our inspiration from the nervous system, which is basically a collection of cells that guide your body through behavioral space using, using memories and goals and so on. Exactly the same thing, it turns out, happens in anatomical space.
primary_topics: Comparison of regenerative abilities across different organisms
content_summary: The speaker discusses the regenerative capabilities of mammals, emphasizing that they are not as efficient as those of some other organisms. They also draw a parallel between the function of the nervous system and the behavior of cells in anatomical space, suggesting that cells may have a form of 'memory' and 'goals' that guide their behavior.
